A **Nazgul**, W, is a [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. They share the [life draining](/wiki/Life_drain "Life drain")-weapon attack of other [wraiths](/wiki/Wraith_\(monster_class\) "Wraith (monster class)"), and also possess the ability to breathe [sleeping](/wiki/Sleep "Sleep") gas.

A player killed by a Nazgul may appear as a [wraith](/wiki/Wraith "Wraith") instead of a [ghost](/wiki/Ghost "Ghost") in their [bones](/wiki/Bones "Bones") file.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [3 History](#History)

- [4 Origin](#Origin)

- [5 Variants](#Variants)

  - [5.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [5.2 SporkHack](#SporkHack)
  - [5.3 UnNetHack](#UnNetHack)
  - [5.4 dNetHack](#dNetHack)
  - [5.5 xNetHack](#xNetHack)
  - [5.6 SpliceHack](#SpliceHack)
  - [5.7 EvilHack](#EvilHack)

- [6 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

- [7 References](#References)

## Generation

Nazgul [are generated with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") [cursed](/wiki/Cursed "Cursed") [rings of invisibility](/wiki/Ring_of_invisibility "Ring of invisibility"), and always receive a [knife](/wiki/Knife "Knife") and [long sword](/wiki/Long_sword "Long sword") similar to the [barrow wight](/wiki/Barrow_wight "Barrow wight").[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

Only nine Nazgul will be generated in any given game, after which they become [extinct](/wiki/Extinct "Extinct"), and they are not a valid form for [polymorph](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph").[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

## Strategy

Players without [sleep resistance](/wiki/Sleep_resistance "Sleep resistance") can be caught off-guard by the Nazgul's sleeping breath, which may leave them free to close in and drain levels or even kill them out right.

Many souvenir hunters [name](/wiki/Name "Name") the Nazgul's rings and attempt to ascend with a set of all nine.

## History

The Nazgul first appears in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0"). From this version to [NetHack 3.0.10](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.10 "NetHack 3.0.10"), the Nazgul's inclusion could be toggled with the TOLKIEN [compile-time option](/wiki/Compile-time_option "Compile-time option") - it becomes a default part of the bestiary in [NetHack 3.1.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.1.0 "NetHack 3.1.0").

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Nazgûl](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nazg%C3%BBl "wikipedia:Nazgûl")***

The Nazgûl (from Black Speech nazg, "ring", and gûl, "wraith, spirit") are derived from the world of Middle-earth created by [J. R. R. Tolkien](/wiki/J._R._R._Tolkien "J. R. R. Tolkien"). They are introduced as "Black Riders" and also called Ringwraiths, Dark Riders, the Nine Riders, or simply the Nine. They were originally nine mortal humans who had succumbed to Sauron's power through wearing Rings of Power, which gave them immortality at the cost of reducing them to invisible wraiths bound to the power of the One Ring and completely under Sauron's control; this is the basis for the cursed rings of invisibility they spawn with in *NetHack*, as well as why only nine ever generate in a given game.

In their early forays, Nazgûl rode on black horses, and they later ride flying monsters that Tolkien described as "pterodactylic". They used fear as their main weapon, though they have also been seen carrying ordinary swords as well as Morgul-knives that reduce their victims to wraiths (hence why players slain by Nazgûl in *NetHack* arise as wraiths.

## Variants

Many variants grant the Nazgul additional traits derived from the works of Tolkien that they appeared in, including their mutual [grudge](/wiki/Grudge "Grudge") against [hobbits](/wiki/Hobbit "Hobbit") derived from Nephi's grudge patch.

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), Nazgul can [hit as a +2 weapon](/wiki/Hits_creatures_as_%2Bx_weapon "Hits creatures as +x weapon"), and [require a +1 weapon to hit](/wiki/Need_%2Bx_weapon_to_hit "Need +x weapon to hit").

### SporkHack

In [SporkHack](/wiki/SporkHack "SporkHack"), Nazgul have a [screaming attack](/index.php?title=Screaming_attack\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Screaming attack (page does not exist)") that [stuns](/wiki/Stun "Stun") you and covers the entire level, making them a prime target for [genocide](/wiki/Genocide "Genocide"). Nazgul also have a mutual grudge against [hobbits](/wiki/Hobbit "Hobbit"), and both will attack each other on sight.

### UnNetHack

In [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack"), Nazgul have a screaming attack similar to SporkHack, but with much shorter range, and also have a mutual grudge against hobbits.

Players killed by a Nazgul in UnNetHack will arise as a [barrow wight](/wiki/Barrow_wight "Barrow wight") if a bones file is created.

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), the presence of Nazgul on a level will cause monsters that are killed to rise as [shades](/wiki/Shade "Shade"). Their born counter decreases each time a Nazgul is killed, meaning they will not stop generating and will not become [extinct](/wiki/Extinct "Extinct") unless they are all left alive.

The [Mordor Ruins Quest](/wiki/Mordor_Ruins_Quest "Mordor Ruins Quest") has several Nazguls:

- The Deep Forest levels each have a 1⁄20 chance of generating a Nazgul at level creation.
- At the edge of the Elven Forest, a Nazgul leads a horde of [orcs](/wiki/Orc_\(monster_class\) "Orc (monster class)") against a group of [elves](/wiki/Elf_\(monster_attribute\) "Elf (monster attribute)") led by an [Elvenqueen](/wiki/Elvenqueen "Elvenqueen"). All monsters are generated on level creation.
- Two Nazgul are generated on the Mordor Wall level of the Mordor Ruins at level creation.

Nazgul can be warded off by [Elbereth](/wiki/Elbereth_\(dNetHack\) "Elbereth (dNetHack)").

### xNetHack

In [xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack"), Nazgul cannot be genocided and have the innate ability to [see invisible](/wiki/See_invisible "See invisible"). Nazgul also possess a shrieking attack that awakens and may stun the player and various nearby monsters within a 10-square radius - they will use this attack less often if the player is not in line-of-sight. The shriek always affects [elves](/wiki/Quendi "Quendi") and will never affect [orcs](/wiki/Orc_\(monster_class\) "Orc (monster class)"), [undead](/wiki/Undead "Undead") and [animals](/wiki/Animal "Animal"). Higher [charisma](/wiki/Charisma "Charisma") gives you a slightly better chance of resisting the shriek's stunning effect.

### SpliceHack

In [SpliceHack](/wiki/SpliceHack "SpliceHack"), Nazgul have a screaming attack, and Nazgul and hobbits will also attack each other.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), Nazgul are made stronger and generate riding [fell beasts](/wiki/Fell_beast "Fell beast") as steeds, which are dangerous creatures in their own right; a Nazgul's scream can also shatter any [glass](/wiki/Glass "Glass") objects in open inventory that have not been [fixed](/wiki/Fixed "Fixed"). Nazgul and hobbits will also attack each other.

## Encyclopedia entry

Immediately, though everything else remained as before, dim and dark, the shapes became terribly clear. He was able to see beneath their black wrappings. There were five tall figures: two standing on the lip of the dell, three advancing. In their white faces burned keen and merciless eyes; under their mantles were long grey robes; upon their grey hairs were helms of silver; in their haggard hands were swords of steel. Their eyes fell on him and pierced him, as they rushed towards him. Desperate, he drew his own sword, and it seemed to him that it flickered red, as if it was a firebrand. Two of the figures halted. The third was taller than the others: his hair was long and gleaming and on his helm was a crown. In one hand he held a long sword, and in the other a knife; both the knife and the hand that held it glowed with a pale light. He sprang forward and bore down on Frodo.

\[ The Fellowship of the Ring, by J.R.R. Tolkien ]

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 472](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/makemon.c#L472)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 720](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/makemon.c#L720)
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1427](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/makemon.c#L1427)

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")
html:
Nazgul

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
W Nazgul
Difficulty 17
Attacks Weapon 1d4 drain life, breath 2d25 sleep
W Nazgul
Difficulty 17
Attacks

Weapon 1d4 drain life, breath 2d25 sleep

Base level 13
Base experience 376
Speed 12
Base AC 0
Base MR 25
Alignment −17 (chaotic)
Frequency (by normal means) 1 (Very rare)
Genocidable Yes
Weight 1450
Nutritional value 0
Size Medium
Resistances Cold, sleep, poison
Resistances conveyed None

A Nazgul:

  • does not breathe.
  • has a head, a couple of arms, and a torso.
  • does not eat. (*)
  • is not a valid polymorphable form.
  • is undead.
  • is male.
  • is normally generated hostile.
  • can follow you to other levels.
  • is strong.
  • can pick up weapons and food.
  • never leaves a corpse.
Reference monst.c#line1895

A Nazgul, W, is a monster that appears in NetHack. They share the life draining-weapon attack of other wraiths, and also possess the ability to breathe sleeping gas.

A player killed by a Nazgul may appear as a wraith instead of a ghost in their bones file.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Strategy
  • 3 History
  • 4 Origin
  • 5 Variants
    • 5.1 SLASH'EM
    • 5.2 SporkHack
    • 5.3 UnNetHack
    • 5.4 dNetHack
    • 5.5 xNetHack
    • 5.6 SpliceHack
    • 5.7 EvilHack
  • 6 Encyclopedia entry
  • 7 References

Generation

Nazgul are generated with cursed rings of invisibility, and always receive a knife and long sword similar to the barrow wight.[1][2]

Only nine Nazgul will be generated in any given game, after which they become extinct, and they are not a valid form for polymorph.[3]

Strategy

Players without sleep resistance can be caught off-guard by the Nazgul's sleeping breath, which may leave them free to close in and drain levels or even kill them out right.

Many souvenir hunters name the Nazgul's rings and attempt to ascend with a set of all nine.

History

The Nazgul first appears in NetHack 3.0.0. From this version to NetHack 3.0.10, the Nazgul's inclusion could be toggled with the TOLKIEN compile-time option - it becomes a default part of the bestiary in NetHack 3.1.0.

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Nazgûl

The Nazgûl (from Black Speech nazg, "ring", and gûl, "wraith, spirit") are derived from the world of Middle-earth created by J. R. R. Tolkien. They are introduced as "Black Riders" and also called Ringwraiths, Dark Riders, the Nine Riders, or simply the Nine. They were originally nine mortal humans who had succumbed to Sauron's power through wearing Rings of Power, which gave them immortality at the cost of reducing them to invisible wraiths bound to the power of the One Ring and completely under Sauron's control; this is the basis for the cursed rings of invisibility they spawn with in NetHack, as well as why only nine ever generate in a given game.

In their early forays, Nazgûl rode on black horses, and they later ride flying monsters that Tolkien described as "pterodactylic". They used fear as their main weapon, though they have also been seen carrying ordinary swords as well as Morgul-knives that reduce their victims to wraiths (hence why players slain by Nazgûl in NetHack arise as wraiths.

Variants

Many variants grant the Nazgul additional traits derived from the works of Tolkien that they appeared in, including their mutual grudge against hobbits derived from Nephi's grudge patch.

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, Nazgul can hit as a +2 weapon, and require a +1 weapon to hit.

SporkHack

In SporkHack, Nazgul have a screaming attack that stuns you and covers the entire level, making them a prime target for genocide. Nazgul also have a mutual grudge against hobbits, and both will attack each other on sight.

UnNetHack

In UnNetHack, Nazgul have a screaming attack similar to SporkHack, but with much shorter range, and also have a mutual grudge against hobbits.

Players killed by a Nazgul in UnNetHack will arise as a barrow wight if a bones file is created.

dNetHack

In dNetHack, the presence of Nazgul on a level will cause monsters that are killed to rise as shades. Their born counter decreases each time a Nazgul is killed, meaning they will not stop generating and will not become extinct unless they are all left alive.

The Mordor Ruins Quest has several Nazguls:

  • The Deep Forest levels each have a 1⁄20 chance of generating a Nazgul at level creation.
  • At the edge of the Elven Forest, a Nazgul leads a horde of orcs against a group of elves led by an Elvenqueen. All monsters are generated on level creation.
  • Two Nazgul are generated on the Mordor Wall level of the Mordor Ruins at level creation.

Nazgul can be warded off by Elbereth.

xNetHack

In xNetHack, Nazgul cannot be genocided and have the innate ability to see invisible. Nazgul also possess a shrieking attack that awakens and may stun the player and various nearby monsters within a 10-square radius - they will use this attack less often if the player is not in line-of-sight. The shriek always affects elves and will never affect orcs, undead and animals. Higher charisma gives you a slightly better chance of resisting the shriek's stunning effect.

SpliceHack

In SpliceHack, Nazgul have a screaming attack, and Nazgul and hobbits will also attack each other.

EvilHack

In EvilHack, Nazgul are made stronger and generate riding fell beasts as steeds, which are dangerous creatures in their own right; a Nazgul's scream can also shatter any glass objects in open inventory that have not been fixed. Nazgul and hobbits will also attack each other.

Encyclopedia entry

Immediately, though everything else remained as before, dim and dark, the shapes became terribly clear. He was able to see beneath their black wrappings. There were five tall figures: two standing on the lip of the dell, three advancing. In their white faces burned keen and merciless eyes; under their mantles were long grey robes; upon their grey hairs were helms of silver; in their haggard hands were swords of steel. Their eyes fell on him and pierced him, as they rushed towards him. Desperate, he drew his own sword, and it seemed to him that it flickered red, as if it was a firebrand. Two of the figures halted. The third was taller than the others: his hair was long and gleaming and on his helm was a crown. In one hand he held a long sword, and in the other a knife; both the knife and the hand that held it glowed with a pale light. He sprang forward and bore down on Frodo.

[ The Fellowship of the Ring, by J.R.R. Tolkien ]

A '''Nazgul''', {{monsym|Nazgul}}, is a [[monster]] that appears in ''[[NetHack]]''. They share the [[life drain]]ing-weapon attack of other [[Wraith (monster class)|wraiths]], and also possess the ability to breathe [[sleep]]ing gas.

A player killed by a Nazgul may appear as a [[wraith]] instead of a [[ghost]] in their [[bones]] file.

==Generation==
Nazgul [[Monster starting inventory|are generated with]] [[cursed]] [[ring of invisibility|rings of invisibility]], and always receive a [[knife]] and [[long sword]] similar to the [[barrow wight]].{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|472|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|720|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}

Only nine Nazgul will be generated in any given game, after which they become [[extinct]], and they are not a valid form for [[polymorph]].{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|1427|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}

==Strategy==
Players without [[sleep resistance]] can be caught off-guard by the Nazgul's sleeping breath, which may leave them free to close in and drain levels or even kill them out right.

Many souvenir hunters [[name]] the Nazgul's rings and attempt to ascend with a set of all nine.

==History==
The Nazgul first appears in [[NetHack 3.0.0]]. From this version to [[NetHack 3.0.10]], the Nazgul's inclusion could be toggled with the TOLKIEN [[compile-time option]] - it becomes a default part of the bestiary in [[NetHack 3.1.0]].

==Origin==
{{wikipedia|Nazgûl}}
The Nazgûl (from Black Speech nazg, "ring", and gûl, "wraith, spirit") are derived from the world of Middle-earth created by [[J. R. R. Tolkien]]. They are introduced as "Black Riders" and also called Ringwraiths, Dark Riders, the Nine Riders, or simply the Nine. They were originally nine mortal humans who had succumbed to Sauron's power through wearing Rings of Power, which gave them immortality at the cost of reducing them to invisible wraiths bound to the power of the One Ring and completely under Sauron's control; this is the basis for the cursed rings of invisibility they spawn with in ''NetHack'', as well as why only nine ever generate in a given game.

In their early forays, Nazgûl rode on black horses, and they later ride flying monsters that Tolkien described as "pterodactylic". They used fear as their main weapon, though they have also been seen carrying ordinary swords as well as Morgul-knives that reduce their victims to wraiths (hence why players slain by Nazgûl in ''NetHack'' arise as wraiths.

==Variants==
Many variants grant the Nazgul additional traits derived from the works of Tolkien that they appeared in, including their mutual [[grudge]] against [[hobbit]]s derived from Nephi's grudge patch.

===SLASH'EM===
In [[SLASH'EM]], Nazgul can [[Hits creatures as +x weapon|hit as a +2 weapon]], and [[Need +x weapon to hit|require a +1 weapon to hit]].

===SporkHack===
In [[SporkHack]], Nazgul have a [[screaming attack]] that [[stun]]s you and covers the entire level, making them a prime target for [[genocide]]. Nazgul also have a mutual grudge against [[hobbit]]s, and both will attack each other on sight.

===UnNetHack===
In [[UnNetHack]], Nazgul have a screaming attack similar to SporkHack, but with much shorter range, and also have a mutual grudge against hobbits.

Players killed by a Nazgul in UnNetHack will arise as a [[barrow wight]] if a bones file is created.

===dNetHack===
In [[dNetHack]], the presence of Nazgul on a level will cause monsters that are killed to rise as [[shade]]s. Their born counter decreases each time a Nazgul is killed, meaning they will not stop generating and will not become [[extinct]] unless they are all left alive.

The [[Mordor Ruins Quest]] has several Nazguls:

* The Deep Forest levels each have a {{frac|20}} chance of generating a Nazgul at level creation.
* At the edge of the Elven Forest, a Nazgul leads a horde of [[Orc (monster class)|orcs]] against a group of [[Elf (monster attribute)|elves]] led by an [[Elvenqueen]]. All monsters are generated on level creation.
* Two Nazgul are generated on the Mordor Wall level of the Mordor Ruins at level creation.

Nazgul can be warded off by [[Elbereth (dNetHack)|Elbereth]].

===xNetHack===
In [[xNetHack]], Nazgul cannot be genocided and have the innate ability to [[see invisible]]. Nazgul also possess a shrieking attack that awakens and may stun the player and various nearby monsters within a 10-square radius - they will use this attack less often if the player is not in line-of-sight. The shriek always affects [[Quendi|elves]] and will never affect [[Orc (monster class)|orcs]], [[undead]] and [[animal]]s. Higher [[charisma]] gives you a slightly better chance of resisting the shriek's stunning effect.

===SpliceHack===
In [[SpliceHack]], Nazgul have a screaming attack, and Nazgul and hobbits will also attack each other.

===EvilHack===
In [[EvilHack]], Nazgul are made stronger and generate riding [[fell beast]]s as steeds, which are dangerous creatures in their own right; a Nazgul's scream can also shatter any [[glass]] objects in open inventory that have not been [[fixed]]. Nazgul and hobbits will also attack each other.

==Encyclopedia entry==
{{encyclopedia|
Immediately, though everything else remained as before, dim and dark, the shapes became terribly clear.  He was able to see beneath their black wrappings.  There were five tall figures:  two standing on the lip of the dell, three advancing. In their white faces burned keen and merciless eyes; under their mantles were long grey robes; upon their grey hairs were helms of silver; in their haggard hands were swords of steel.  Their eyes fell on him and pierced him, as they rushed towards him.  Desperate, he drew his own sword, and it seemed to him that it flickered red, as if it was a firebrand.  Two of the figures halted.  The third was taller than the others:  his hair was long and gleaming and on his helm was a crown.  In one hand he held a long sword, and in the other a knife; both the knife and the hand that held it glowed with a pale light.  He sprang forward and bore down on Frodo.
|[ The Fellowship of the Ring, by J.R.R. Tolkien ]}}
